Teacher_Question: What's your favorite part about recess?
Student_Response: Playing on the monkey bars! And sometimes I can go all the way across without falling! But yesterday I fell but I didn't cry.

Teacher_Question: Can you tell me how you solved this math problem?
Student_Response: Um... first I counted on my fingers, then I drew little circles, and then... um... I forgot. Can I start over?

Teacher_Question: What do you think will happen next in the story?
Student_Response: I think the dragon is gonna become best friends with the princess because they both like cookies, just like me!

Teacher_Question: Why do you think it rains?
Student_Response: The clouds get really heavy and full of water and then they're like 'I'm too heavy!' and they drop all the water down!

Teacher_Question: What did you do over the weekend?
Student_Response: We went to my grandma's house and she made cookies and my little brother ate four but I only got two and it wasn't fair!

Teacher_Question: How did you help someone today?
Student_Response: I shared my blue crayon with Tommy because his broke, even though blue is my favorite color.

Teacher_Question: What's the hardest part about being in second grade?
Student_Response: Writing in cursive is really hard. The letters look like spaghetti and my hand gets tired.

Teacher_Question: If you could be any animal, what would you be and why?
Student_Response: A dolphin because they get to swim all day and they're super smart and they help people who are lost in the ocean!

Teacher_Question: What makes a good friend?
Student_Response: Someone who shares their snacks and doesn't push in line and plays with you even when the popular kids want to play with them.

Teacher_Question: Why is it important to eat vegetables?
Student_Response: My mom says they make you strong like a superhero but I think they taste like grass. But I still eat them sometimes.

Teacher_Question: What do you want to be when you grow up?
Student_Response: I wanna be a ninja-astronaut-veterinarian! And also maybe a teacher, but only on Tuesdays.

Teacher_Question: How do plants grow?
Student_Response: They need water and sun and dirt and love! My plant at home died because I gave it too much love... and maybe too much water.

Teacher_Question: What's your favorite book and why?
Student_Response: Pete the Cat because he steps in strawberries but doesn't cry about his white shoes getting red!

Teacher_Question: How did you feel when you got the answer right?
Student_Response: I was so excited I did a happy dance in my chair but then Mrs. Johnson said to save my dancing for music class.

Teacher_Question: What's the most interesting thing you learned today?
Student_Response: That butterflies taste with their feet! That's so weird! I'm glad I don't have to taste my socks when I walk.

Teacher_Question: Why are you standing?
Student_Response: I didn't do it first! Tommy was standing and then Michael and then I just needed to see the board better!

Teacher_Question: Why aren't you working on your assignment?
Student_Response: My pencil broke and then I had to sharpen it but the sharpener wasn't working right and then I saw a butterfly outside...

Teacher_Question: Why are you talking during quiet time?
Student_Response: But I had to tell Jenny about my new puppy! It was really important and I whispered... kind of.

Teacher_Question: What happened to make you push your classmate?
Student_Response: He took my eraser first and wouldn't give it back and then he said my drawing was ugly!

Teacher_Question: Why did you leave your seat without permission?
Student_Response: I had to throw my tissue away and the garbage can was all the way over there and I forgot to ask.

Teacher_Question: Why aren't your materials ready for class?
Student_Response: My baby sister put my folder in the toilet this morning and my mom had to dry it with a hair dryer!

Teacher_Question: Why are you making those noises during work time?
Student_Response: I'm just humming my thinking song! It helps me concentrate better, like how dad listens to music when he works!

Teacher_Question: Why did you take Sarah's pencil?
Student_Response: I was just borrowing it! Mine disappeared and I think the pencil monster under my desk ate it.

Teacher_Question: Why aren't you in line with the rest of the class?
Student_Response: I was tying my shoe and everyone walked really fast and didn't wait for me!

Teacher_Question: Why did you run in the hallway?
Student_Response: I wasn't running! I was speed walking because I really really really had to go to the bathroom!

Teacher_Question: What would you do if you were the teacher for a day?
Student_Response: We would have recess ALL day and eat ice cream for lunch and everyone gets a gold star even if they're being silly!

Teacher_Question: Why is there a frog in your desk?
Student_Response: He's my new science project! I found him at recess and he looked lonely so I gave him some of my sandwich.

Teacher_Question: How did your sandwich end up on the ceiling?
Student_Response: I was trying to see if it would stick like in that experiment we did, but I threw it too hard and now it won't come down.

Teacher_Question: Why are you wearing your shoes on the wrong feet?
Student_Response: Because my toes were having an argument and needed to switch sides to make up with each other!

Teacher_Question: What happened to your homework?
Student_Response: Well, my dog was hungry, and the homework looked like a sandwich, and... um... can I do it again?

Teacher_Question: Why is there glitter all over the classroom floor?
Student_Response: It's not glitter, it's fairy dust! The tooth fairy must have spilled some when she was checking for loose teeth.

Teacher_Question: How did you lose your tooth during math class?
Student_Response: I was counting really hard and my tooth got excited and jumped out! It did a flip and everything!

Teacher_Question: Why are there potato chips in your water bottle?
Student_Response: I wanted to make soup like we learned about in social studies, but I forgot to bring a spoon.

Teacher_Question: What made you decide to give yourself a haircut during art?
Student_Response: I thought my bangs were getting too long and kept tickling my nose during the art project.

Teacher_Question: Why is there a sock puppet talking during science?
Student_Response: That's not me, that's Professor Wooley! He's teaching us about clouds because he's a sock scientist.

Teacher_Question: How did your backpack get stuck in the tree?
Student_Response: I was trying to make it fly like we learned birds do in science, but it didn't have enough feathers.

Teacher_Question: Why are there stickers all over your face?
Student_Response: They're reward stickers! I gave them to myself because I remembered to brush my teeth this morning.

Teacher_Question: What happened to make the class hamster turn blue?
Student_Response: We were learning about colors and I wanted to see if hamsters could change color like chameleons.

Teacher_Question: Why is there playdough in the computer keyboard?
Student_Response: I was trying to make it type faster by giving it something squishy to press the buttons with!

Teacher_Question: How did your little brother's toy car end up in the fish tank?
Student_Response: I think it wanted to learn how to swim with the fish. It jumped out of my pocket during show and tell!

Teacher_Question: Why do you think the main character felt sad in the story?
Student_Response: Because his ice cream fell on the ground and that happened to me once and I cried but my mom got me a new one!

Teacher_Question: What was your favorite part of the story we just read?
Student_Response: When the dog learned to fly because my dog can't fly but I wish he could and we could go to the moon together!

Teacher_Question: Can you tell me what happened at the beginning of the story?
Student_Response: OK so first there was this girl and she had a purple bicycle and she saw a butterfly and then... um... can I look at the pictures again?

Teacher_Question: How would you feel if you were in the story?
Student_Response: I would be super brave and make friends with the dragon right away and invite him to my birthday party!

Teacher_Question: What do you think the word 'determined' means in this story?
Student_Response: It means when you really really really want to do something, like how I'm determined to eat all my Halloween candy!

Teacher_Question: Why did the boy give his sandwich to the hungry dog?
Student_Response: Because sharing is caring! And one time I shared my cookies with my friend when she was sad and it made her happy!

Teacher_Question: What lesson did we learn from this story?
Student_Response: That you should always be nice to dragons because they might be having a bad day and need a hug... but be careful of their fire!

Teacher_Question: How is this story similar to the one we read yesterday?
Student_Response: Both of them had a cat! And both cats could talk which is weird because my cat only says meow.

Teacher_Question: What do you think will happen to the lost kitten?
Student_Response: I think its mommy is going to find it and they'll have a big party with tuna fish cake and invite all the neighborhood cats!

Teacher_Question: Why did the girl in the story make that choice?
Student_Response: Because her grandma told her not to talk to wolves, but the wolf was wearing a really cool hat so she forgot!

Teacher_Question: How did the characters solve their problem?
Student_Response: They used teamwork! Just like how me and my little sister worked together to reach the cookie jar... but don't tell my mom.

Teacher_Question: What clues tell us that it was autumn in the story?
Student_Response: The leaves were orange and red and the kids were wearing jackets and there was a big pile of leaves to jump in!

Teacher_Question: Why was the giant friendly after all?
Student_Response: He just needed a friend and some cookies! Maybe he was grumpy because he didn't have any breakfast.

Teacher_Question: What would you have done differently if you were the main character?
Student_Response: I would have brought my superhero cape and flew over the river instead of building a bridge!

Teacher_Question: Can you describe the setting of the story?
Student_Response: It was in a magical forest with sparkly trees and talking mushrooms and a unicorn house with rainbow windows!

Teacher_Question: Why was the magic key important to the story?
Student_Response: Because it could open the door to the candy room! But they should have gotten two keys in case they lost one.

Teacher_Question: How did the character's feelings change from the beginning to the end?
Student_Response: First she was scared of the dark but then she got a night light and now she's super brave like me!

Teacher_Question: What made the rainbow fish special?
Student_Response: He had shiny scales but he learned that friends are better than being shiny, like how my light-up shoes aren't as cool as playing with friends.

Teacher_Question: Why couldn't the little engine climb the mountain at first?
Student_Response: Because he kept saying 'I think I can't' instead of 'I think I can!' My mom says that to me when I can't tie my shoes.

Teacher_Question: What does the word 'enormous' mean in this sentence?
Student_Response: It means really really really big, like bigger than my dad and he's the biggest person I know!
